children.text:
Content Standard 1: Skills and Techniques
Students shall demonstrate and apply the essential skills and techniques to produce music.
Sing

Sing a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • eighth note and sixteenth note patterns
  • variety of tempi (e.g., andante, moderato)
  • major tonalities
  • dynamic levels- pianissimo (pp), piano (p), mezzo piano (mp), mezzo forte (mf), forte (f), and fortissimo (ff)
  • change in dynamic levels- crescendo and decrescendo
  • and meters
  • countermelodies

Sing a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • pattern of a dotted quarter note followed by an eighth note or eighth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., lento, presto)
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • and meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies (e.g., two-part lines, twelve-bar blues)

Sing a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • pattern of a dotted eighth note followed by a sixteenth note or sixteenth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., grave, vivace)
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • , or cut time, meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies (e.g., theme and variations, three-part lines)

Sing a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • syncopation
  • variety of tempi
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • compound and mixed meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies
Play

Play a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • eighth note and sixteenth note patterns
  • variety of tempi (e.g., andante, moderato)
  • major tonalities
  • dynamic levels- pianissimo (pp), piano (p), mezzo piano (mp), mezzo forte (mf), forte (f), and fortissimo (ff)
  • change in dynamic levels- crescendo and decrescendo
  • and meters

Play a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • pattern of a dotted quarter note followed by an eighth note or eighth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., lento, presto)
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • and meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies (e.g., two-part lines, twelve-bar blues)

Play a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • pattern of a dotted eighth note followed by a sixteenth note or sixteenth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., grave, vivace)
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • , or cut time, meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies (e.g., theme and variations, three-part lines)

Play a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • syncopation
  • variety of tempi
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • compound and mixed meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies
Techniques

Refine correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
  • posture-vocal and instrumental
  • breathing
  • phrasing
  • articulation
Demonstrate and respond to simple conducting patterns

Refine correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
  • posture-vocal and instrumental
  • breathing
  • phrasing
  • articulation
Interpret and respond to a conductor

Refine correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
  • posture-vocal and instrumental
  • breathing
  • phrasing
  • articulation
Interpret and respond to a conductor

Refine correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
  • posture-vocal and instrumental
  • breathing
  • phrasing
  • articulation
Interpret and respond to artistic conducting
Read

Read
  • eighth note and sixteenth note patterns
  • variety of tempi (e.g., andante, moderato)
  • more complex melodic patterns (e.g., do-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti-do/1-2-3-4-5-6-7-8, major scale)
  • dynamic levels- pianissimo (pp), piano (p), mezzo piano (mp), mezzo forte (mf), forte (f), and fortissimo (ff)
  • change in dynamic level-crescendo, decrescendo
  • and meters
Identify notes written on the lines and spaces of the treble clef and bass clef

Apply knowledge of symbols and terms in reading music
  • repeat sign
  • treble clef
  • bass clef
  • bar line and double bar line
  • time signatures
  • fermata
  • simple key signatures

Read
  • pattern of a dotted quarter note followed by an eighth note or eighth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., lento, presto)
  • melodic patterns that include accidentals
  • various dynamic levels
  • and meter
  • various forms and harmonies (e.g., two-part lines, twelve-bar blues)
Identify notes written on the lines, spaces, and ledger lines of the treble clef and bass clef

Apply knowledge of symbols and terms in reading music
  • accidentals
  • first and second endings
  • da capo (D.C.)
  • dal segno (D.S.)
  • Coda

Read
  • pattern of a dotted eighth note followed by a sixteenth note or sixteenth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., grave, vivace)
  • various dynamic levels
  • , or cut time, meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies (e.g., theme and variations, three-part lines)
  • the intervals within the staff (e.g., Major 6, Perfect 5, Perfect 4, Major 3, Major 2, octave)
Identify notes written on the lines and spaces of the grand staff

Apply knowledge of symbols and terms in reading music
  • additional key signatures
  • grand staff

Read
  • syncopation
  • variety of tempi
  • various dynamic levels
  • compound and mixed meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies
  • the intervals within the staff (e.g., Major 6, Perfect 5, Perfect 4, Major 3, Major 2, octave)
Identify notes written on the lines, spaces, and ledger lines of the grand staff

Apply knowledge of symbols and terms in reading music
  • multiple key signatures within a composition
Notate

Notate
  • eighth note and sixteenth note patterns
  • and time signatures

Notate
  • pattern of a dotted quarter note followed by an eighth note or eighth rest
  • and time signature

Notate
  • pattern of a dotted eighth note followed by a sixteenth note or sixteenth rest
  • , or cut time, time signature

Notate
  • syncopation
Perform
Beginning Vocal
Sing correctly using appropriate breath support and control throughout the vocal range
Explore the changing voice and vocal range through warm-ups and selected repertoire
Sing a variety of vocal repertoire in unison at an appropriate level of difficulty alone or in groups
Sing using proper vocal technique
Sing appropriate repertoire written in treble clef
Demonstrate through performance an understanding of the language of music
Intermediate Vocal
Sing expressively with attention to dynamics, phrasing, and articulation
Explore the changing voice and vocal range through warm-ups, breathing exercises, and selected repertoire
Sing a variety of vocal repertoire in unison and two-part at an appropriate level of difficulty alone or in groups
Sing using proper vocal technique
Read and sing appropriate repertoire written in treble clef
Demonstrate through performance an understanding of the language of music
Advanced Vocal
Sing expressively with attention to blend, balance, dynamics, phrasing, and articulation
Explore the changing voice and expanding vocal range though warm-ups, breathing exercises, and appropriate repertoire
Sing a variety of vocal repertoire in unison, two-part, and independent parts at an appropriate level of difficulty alone or in groups
Sing using proper vocal technique
Sight read and sight sing appropriate repertoire written in treble clef
Demonstrate through performance an understanding of the language of music

Content Standard 2: Creative Expression
Students shall demonstrate creative expression through music.
Improvise
Improvise rhythmic variations on familiar melodies
Improvise rhythms, melodies, and/or accompaniments
Improvise using a variety of sound sources (e.g., computer, electronic sounds)
Improvise rhythmic and melodic variations in a given style and meter (e.g., reggae, blues)
Compose/Arrange
Compose a four-measure phrase
Arrange familiar songs using musical expression
Compose a four-measure phrase with accompaniment
Arrange familiar songs with accompaniment
Compose an original melodic line with accompaniment
Arrange unfamiliar songs using musical expression
Compose an original song using various instruments
Arrange unfamiliar songs with accompaniment
Movement
Respond to music through movement (e.g., traditional and improvised conducting patterns)
Respond to music through movement (e.g., create movement to outline musical form)
Respond to music through movement (e.g., create choreography to songs for performance)
Respond to music through movement (e.g., create a song along with movement to teach to younger students)
Perform
Beginning Vocal
Sing selected repertoire with appropriate dynamics
Intermediate Vocal
Sing selected repertoire with creative expression
Advanced Vocal
Sing selected repertoire with creative expression and artistic interpretation

Content Standard 3: Critical Analysis
Students shall listen to, analyze, describe, and evaluate a variety of music.
Listen/Analyze

Identify musical instruments by sight and sound
  • string
  • brass
  • woodwind
  • percussion
  • electronic

Recognize musical form
  • theme and variations
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer

Identify musical timbre
  • brass
  • string
  • percussion
  • woodwind
  • electronic
  • vocal

Recognize musical texture
  • solo
  • small groups
  • large ensemble

Compare and contrast musical form
  • popular and imitative forms
  • twelve-bar blues
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer

Identify musical sounds
  • electronic
  • non-traditional
  • genres (e.g., women's ensemble, men's ensemble)
Analyze various musical forms
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer

Distinguish musical sounds
  • western and non-western
  • traditional and non-traditional
  • cross cultural
Analyze various musical forms
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer
Evaluate
Evaluate performances and compositions using a student-generated rubric
Evaluate performances and compositions using a student-generated rubric
Evaluate performances and compositions using a student-generated rubric
Evaluate performances and compositions using a student-generated rubric

Content Standard 4: Connections
Students shall demonstrate and apply knowledge of connections between music and other disciplines.
Historical/ Cultural

Respond to music from various cultures, historical periods, and/or events (e.g., world music, folk music, jazz, spirituals)
  • listening
  • singing
  • moving
  • playing

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts (e.g., theatre, ballet)
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts (e.g., social studies)

Respond to music from various cultures, historical periods, and/or events (e.g., popular, Classical)
  • listening
  • singing
  • moving
  • playing

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts
Investigate music from various cultures, historical periods, and/or events (e.g., singing, listening, researching)

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts
Investigate music from various cultures, historical periods, and/or events (e.g., singing, listening, researching)

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts
Research
Research career opportunities in music (e.g., business, education, performance, music therapy, technology)
Research career opportunities in music (e.g., business, education, performance, music therapy, technology)
Research career opportunities in music (e.g., business, education, performance, music therapy, technology)
Research career opportunities in music (e.g., business, education, performance, music therapy, technology)
Perform
Beginning Instrumental
Sing music from various cultures, historical periods, and/or events
Intermediate Instrumental
Sing music from various cultures, historical periods, and/or events
Advanced Instrumental
Sing music from various cultures, historical periods, and/or events
